On 9/21/05, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
> Robert Watkin=
s wrote:
>
> > Certain output streams automatically convert \n to the line =
seperator
> > of the platform you are on.
>
> Really? Which ones? That's ce=
rtainly not standard behavior, and it's not
> true of System.out, which is =
the stream at issue here.

Actually, it's the writers, not the output strea=
ms that do this. Sorry
for not being precise. (OutputStreams  wouldn't do t=
his because they
operate at a byte level). Not all the writers do it either=
... I forget
which ones (though I suspect it's probably FileWriter)

For th=
e code under question, it's hard to tell without knowing what
the function =
call does, but note that the println() family of methods
for PrintStream _d=
o_ use the System property.

> In general code should not be written to dep=
end on the system line
> separator. That worked well when programs and data=
 spent their entire
> lives on one computer, or perhaps a few computers all=
 running the same
> OS. In the world of the Internet and Java, that's no lo=
nger true.
> Programs should explicitly specify the line separator characte=
r(s) they
> write or read. Their output should not vary from one platform t=
o the next.

That's not strictly true, Elliotte. It depends on the nature o=
f what
you are doing. In particular, when writing to files, then you should=

respect the line seperator, otherwise the text-editing tools of the
platfo=
rm will have problems.

Similarly, with console output (the case in point),=
 you should use the
correct line seperator, otherwise the console may not r=
ender the
output correctly.

Of course, if you are writing a network applic=
ation, then you should
use a fixed line seperator, which by convention woul=
d be '\n'.

Similary with character encoding, you should use the platform d=
efault
if you are writing for human output (e.g. files, console, or display=
),
but should use a standard convention like UTF-8 or UTF-16 when
transmitt=
ing.
